channel.title: Yes, i'm a noob. Decryption
channel.description:
So MITB, i'm a noob. I'm not going to lie. I need help with a decryption, I can't seem to find a MD5 Decrpyter which will decrpyt it. What a pain in the ass :/
[b]Edit:[/b] This is the questions section isn't it :/ I take it I have to throw in a question. Erm, can you help me, please? ;)
Please help MITB.
"b0518841a9ec6f56baf8b2d58dd1890b"
Rawr.

item.title: Yes, i'm a noob. Decryption
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“nade, post:42, topic:403234”]I remember in the 11th grade (I was 16) a friend and I were generating large lists of md5 hashes 4-6 characters and storing them in text files.

So if you wanted to reverse: b0518841a9ec6f56baf8b2d58dd1890b

You will search for it in b05.txt

and it will have an entry: b0518841a9ec6f56baf8b2d58dd1890b:urgaylol

We gave up after we filled our removable storage to 40GB. I was a head of my time. Srsly[/quote]

a lil sad ur still doing the same stuff to this day -.-

Read full topic

@Jython wrote:

Mopman:

What’s to not understand? You trade-off storage for time, because looking up is quicker than brute forcing…

it’s not as simple as a basic huge hash look-up table
don’t kid yourself, only provide input if you know what you’re talking about

item.title: Yes, i'm a noob. Decryption
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

You’re basically right, except that BCrypt is also built on a strong encryption, whereas MD5 as a hash algorithm is known to be broken. It has collision flaws coming out the wazoo.

But yes, you could do that if you really wanted to. Every language in the world has a BCrypt library though, so why go to the effort when a very secure oneliner is there for you already?

Also, even 100x MD5 is still much faster than normal BCrypt implementation defaults, so you’d have to do a lot more than that.

Read full topic

item.title: Yes, i'm a noob. Decryption
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:23, topic:403234”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=500291.msg3660941#msg3660941 date=1310350889]
Regardless what you use, you need to use some type of unique, per-user salt with the hash, to make it immune to pre-computed hash tables (like rainbow tables).
[/quote]

Not with BCrypt, salting is built into the algorithm.

EDIT: I guess “not with” is a bit misleading, what I mean is you can’t have BCrypt without salting, it requires it, so most implementations (every one I’ve seen) will randomly generate one at hash time if you don’t provide one of your own, so it’s not something the user needs worry about.[/quote]

To me, it looks like the only strength to BCrypt is the required salting and the configurable iterations of the hash function, it seems to me like you could do the same with any hash function to make it ‘secure’, even md5 (but plug in anything, sha1, sha256, whatever), psuedo-code to follow:

function bcrypt_equivalent(password, salt = random_salt(), iterations = 100, hash_func = MD5){
hash = hash_func(password+salt);
for(i = 0; i < iterations-1; ++i)
hash = hash_func(hash+salt);
return hash;
}

What’s the difference? Even MD5 is impossible to bruteforce with enough iterations.

Read full topic

item.description:
@z wrote:

Isn’t a rainbow table just a pre-hashed list of passwords? Basically if you have a good rainbow table, you just look for a hash that matches the one you’re searching for and then it’ll return the password? I’ve never understood it myself either…

Read full topic

item.title: Yes, i'm a noob. Decryption
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Regardless what you use, you need to use some type of unique, per-user salt with the hash, to make it immune to pre-computed hash tables (like rainbow tables).

Not with BCrypt, salting is built into the algorithm.

EDIT: I guess “not with” is a bit misleading, what I mean is you can’t have BCrypt without salting, it requires it, so most implementations (every one I’ve seen) will randomly generate one at hash time if you don’t provide one of your own, so it’s not something the user needs worry about.

Read full topic

item.title: Yes, i'm a noob. Decryption
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

“Best Hash” is pretty subjective and probably means nothing. I think most people agree that SHA1 is probably still sufficient, I’ve also seen people use SHA256 and BCrypt. Regardless what you use, you need to use some type of unique, per-user salt with the hash, to make it immune to pre-computed hash tables (like rainbow tables).

Read full topic
